case_name: State of U.P. v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 369 of 1957 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 369 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 27, 1956, of the Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in Civil Misc. Application No. 17 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated the January 27, 1956, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  at Lucknow in Civil Misc. Applic

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on February 16, 1961 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR., J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Allahabad

facts.text: Respondent filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution against imposition of stamp duty by Collector of Sitapur of Rs. 85,595/7/- and penalty of Rs 5/-, praying the order be quashed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying that the imposition of stamp duty by the Collector of Sitapur, of Rs. 85,595/7/- and a penalty of Rs 5/- was against law and companyld number be realized against him and prayed that the order be quashed.,,

facts.text: On September 12, 1948, the respondent executed a wakf by oral recitation of Sigha and then it was written on a stamped paper which was signed by the respondent and attested by witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: On September 12, 1948, the, respondent executed a wakf by oral recitation of Sigha and then it was written on a stamped paper which was signed by the respondent and attested by, Witness.

facts.text: On September 15, 1948, the wakf document was presented to the Collector for his opinion under s. 31 as to the duty chargeable.

anchor.surface_text: On September 15, 1948, it was presented to the Collector for his opinion under s. 31 as to the duty chargeable. As the Collector himself was in doubt, he referred the matter to the Board of Revenue

facts.text: Collector referred the matter to the Board of Revenue which held that the document was liable to duty in accordance with Art. 58 of the Stamp Act.

anchor.surface_text: As the Collector himself was in doubt, he referred the matter to the Board of Revenue which, after a fairly long time, held that the document was liable to duty in accordance with Art. 58 of the Stamp Act.

facts.text: On October 29, 1951, the Collector held that Rs. 85,598/7/- were payable as stamp duty and ordered deposit within fifteen days.

anchor.surface_text: On October 29, 1951, the Collector held that Rs. 85,598/7/- were payable as stamp duty and ordered that it be deposited within fifteen days.

facts.text: Notice of Collector's order served on respondent on November 10, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Notice to this effect was served on the respondent on November, 10, 1951.

facts.text: Respondent filed Art. 226 petition in High Court, dismissed on November 3, 1952 as premature.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondent filed a petition in the High Court under Art. 226 which was dismissed on November 3, 1952 on the ground that it was premature.

facts.text: On February 2, 1954, further notice served on respondent to deposit stamp duty plus penalty of Rs. 5/- within a month or face s.48 proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On February 2, 1954, a further numberice was served upon the respondent to deposit the amount of the stamp duty plus the penalty of Rs. 5/- within a month otherwise proceedings would be taken against him under s. 48 of the Stamp Act.

facts.text: On March 1, 1954, respondent filed another Art. 226 petition in Allahabad High Court challenging stamp duty and penalty, praying certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on March 1 1944, the respondent filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Allahabad High Court challenging the legality of the, imposition of the stamp duty and the penalty and prayed for a writ of certiorari.

facts.text: Full bench of Allahabad High Court quashed the order of the Collector.

anchor.surface_text: A full bench of the High Court quashed the order of the Collector and the State of U.P. has companye in appeal to this Court.

facts.text: State of U.P. appealed to Supreme Court on certificate by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Allahabad on a certificate granted by that companyrt.

facts.text: Document submitted to Collector for opinion under s. 31.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the document in dispute was submitted to the Collector for his opinion under a. 31 and the opinion of the Collector was sought as to what the duty should be.

facts.text: High Court held that production under s.33 means in evidence or for reliance by parties.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with these words the High Court held- With all respect, therefore, we agree that the learned Judges deciding Chuni Lal Burmans  1  case took a companyrect view of the words is produced or companyes in the performance of his functions used in Section 33 of the Act to mean that production of the instrument companycerned in evidence or for the purpose of placing reliance upon it by one party or the other.

facts.text: Collector determined duty after long delay and impounded the document.

anchor.surface_text: After an inordinately long delay, the Collector determined the amount of duty payable and impounded the document.

facts.text: Instrument not produced as evidence or for acting upon like registration or endorsement under s.32, but for advice on duty.

anchor.surface_text: The instrument in dispute was number produced as a piece of evidence number for its being acted upon e.g. registration, number for endorsement as under s. 32 of the Stamp Act but was merely brought before the Collector for seeking his advise as to what the proper duty would be.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal depends on interpretation of ss. 31, 32 and 33 of the Stamp Act.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this appeal depends upon the interpretation of ss, 31, 32 and 33 of the Stamp Act.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of s. 31 provides-, S. 31 1  When any instrument,, whether executed or not and whether previously stamped or not,, is brought to the Collector and. the person bringing it applies to have the opinion of that officer as to the duty  if any  with which it is chargeable, and pays a fee of such amount  not exceeding five rupees and not less than eight annas  as the Collector may in each case direct, the Collector shall determine the duty  if any  with which, in his judgment, the instrument is chargeable.

concepts.interpretation: Section complete by itself; Collector determines duty and no further action unless under s.32 endorsement requested.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 32 of the Act when such an instrument is brought to the Collector, under s. 31 and he determines that it was already fully stamped or he determines the duty which is payable on such a document and that duty is paid, the Collector shall certify by endorsement on the instrument presented that full duty with which it is chargeable has been paid and upon such endorsement being made, the instrument shall be deemed to be fully stamped or not chargeable to duty as the case may be

concepts.interpretation: Endorsement only if presented within one month of execution; separate from s.31.

anchor.surface_text: Then follows s. 33 which is as follows S. 33 Every person having by law or consent of parties authority to receive evidence, and every person in charge of a public office, except an officer of police, before whom an instrument, chargeable, in his opinion, with duty, is produced or comes in the performance of his functions, shall, if it appears to him that such instrument is not duly stamped impound the same. For that purpose every such person shall examine every instrument so chargeable and so produced or coming before him in order t ascertain whether it is stamped with a stamp of the value and description required by the law in force in British India when such instrument was executed or first executed

concepts.interpretation: Applies to instruments produced as evidence or for acting upon (e.g. registration); does not cover seeking opinion under s.31.

arguments.claim: Instrument brought under s.31 not produced as evidence, for acting upon, or endorsement under s.32, but merely for advice on duty; thus outside s.33

anchor.surface_text: The instrument in dispute was not produced as a piece of evidence not for its being acted upon e.g. registration, not for endorsement as under s. 32 of the Stamp Act but was merely brought before the Collector for seeking his advise as to what the proper duty would be.

arguments.claim: Words in s.33 refer to production as evidence before judicial officers or functions like registration; do not cover s.31 duty determination

anchor.surface_text: The words every person before whom any instrument is produced or comes in the performance of his functions refer firstly to production before judicial or other officers performing judicial functions as evidence of any fact to be proved and secondly refer to other officers who have to perform any function

arguments.claim: s.31 complete by itself; Collector determines duty and ends; s.33 does not apply to acts under s.31; functus officio after determination

anchor.surface_text: They do not cover the acts which fall within the scope of s. 31, because that section is complete by itself and it ends by saying that the Collector shall determine the duty with which, in his judgment, the instrument is chargeable, if it is chargeable at all. Section 31 does not postulate anything further

arguments.claim: No time limit in s.31 for seeking opinion, unlike s.32; scheme of Act protects seeker of opinion from s.33 penalties unless further action taken

anchor.surface_text: Section 31 places no limitation in regard to the time and there is no reason why any time limit should be imposed in regard to seeking of opinion as to the duty payable. ... after the determination of the duty the Collector becomes functus officio and the provisions of s. 33 have no application.

arguments.claim: Functus officio doctrine applies as in Collector Ahmednagar v. Rambhau (certificate signed, cannot later impound); similar here after s.31 determination

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of functus officio was applied in several cases Collector, Ahmednagar v. , Rambhau Tukaram Nirhali  2 . In that case a certificate of sale had been signed but the certificate was not duly stamped which was pointed out when it was sent to the Sub- Registrar for registration.

arguments.claim: Extraordinary if person merely seeking s.31 opinion on executed instrument liable to impoundment penalties without intent to use as evidence or effectuate

anchor.surface_text: It would be an extraordinary position if a person seeking the advice of the Collector and not wanting to rely upon an instrument as evidence of any fact to be proved not wanting to do any further act in regard to the instrument so as to effectuate its operation should also be liable to the penalties

holdings.text: The instrument brought before the Collector under s.31 was not produced or came in the performance of his functions within the meaning of s.33 so as to attract the power to impound.

anchor.surface_text: What has to be seen is what is the consequence of a person applying to a Collector for his determination as to the proper duty on an instrument. The submission on behalf of the State  appellant  was that if an instrument whether stamped or number is submitted for the opinion of the Collector before it is executed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Instrument submitted merely for advice on duty, not as evidence or for acting upon like registration or endorsement; s.33 applies to different contexts.

holdings.text: The words 'produced or comes in the performance of his functions' in s.33 refer to production as evidence before judicial officers or for official functions like registration, not for seeking duty opinion under s.31.

anchor.surface_text: The words every person before whom any instrument is produced or comes in the performance of his functions refer firstly to production before judicial or other officers performing judicial functions as evidence of any fact to be proved and secondly refer to other officers who have to perform any function

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation distinguishing judicial evidence production and administrative acts like registration from s.31 procedure; adopts and expands High Court view.

holdings.text: Section 31 is complete by itself; upon determining the duty chargeable, the Collector has no further duty or power under that section.

anchor.surface_text: They do not cover the acts which fall within the scope of s. 31, because that section is complete by itself and it ends by saying that the Collector shall determine the duty with which, in his judgment, the instrument is chargeable, if it is chargeable at all. Section 31 does not postulate anything further

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language ends with determination; no provision for further action like impounding; harmonious construction with s.33.

holdings.text: There is no distinction in powers and duties of Collector under s.31 for executed versus unexecuted instruments; same procedure applies.

anchor.surface_text: It was conceded that if the instrument is unexecuted i.e. not signed, and the opinion of the Collector is sought, he has to give his opinion and return it with his opinion to the person seeking his opinion. The language in regard to exe- cuted and unstamped documents is notdifferent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit statutory language identical; no basis for differentiation argued by State.

holdings.text: After determining duty under s.31, Collector becomes functus officio; provisions of s.33 have no application; cannot impound the instrument.

anchor.surface_text: Section 31 places no limitation in regard to the time and there is no reason why any time limit should be imposed in regard to seeking of opinion as to the duty payable. ... after the determination of the duty the Collector becomes functus officio and the provisions of s. 33 have no application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.31 scheme protects opinion seekers; no time limit unlike s.32; extraordinary consequences otherwise; applies functus officio doctrine per precedents.

holdings.text: As soon as the Collector determined the duty under s.31 he became functus officio and could not impound under s.33; consequential proceedings invalid.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous application of functus officio precedents (e.g., judge after signing certificate); s.31 determination exhausts power.

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of functus officio was applied in several cases Collector, Ahmednagar v. , Rambhau Tukaram Nirhali 2 . In that case a certificate of sale had been signed but the certificate was number duly stamped which was pointed out when it was sent to the Sub- Registrar for registration. The Sub-Registrar informed the Judge about it and the Judge got back the certificate from the purchaser and thinking that he had power to impound the document and to impose a penalty asked for the opinion of the high Court and it was held that after he had signed it he was functus officio and companyld number act any further and companyld number impound it.

Section 31 does not postulate anything further

anchor.surface_text: Section 31 places no limitation in regard to the time and there is no reason why any time limit should be imposed in regard to seeking of opinion as to the duty payable. ... after the determination of the duty the Collector becomes functus officio and the provisions of s. 33 have no application.
